properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall amounts reaching 50 millimetres are expected over the Blanc-Sablon area as post-tropical Teddy will track across the Gulf of St Lawrence. Rain will begin overnight tonight and end Thursday morning. For more information on this system's development, please refer to Environment and Climate Change Canada's tropical cyclone information statement: https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/hurricane-forecasts-facts/products.html. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Tropical Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Tropical storm force winds ahead of now Post-Tropical Storm Teddy are expected over the regions, but will remain just below wind warning criteria. Potential wind gusts: 65 to 80 km/h over exposed areas and along parts of the coast. Locations: The Annapolis Valley, northern Nova Scotia, and western Cape Breton. Time span: tonight, with a second period of strong winds likely on Wednesday. Remarks: Strong northeasterly winds will persist tonight ahead of Post-Tropical Storm Teddy. Winds are expected to remain below wind warning criteria, but could still gust up to 80 km/h over exposed areas and along parts of the coast. A second round of strong northwesterly winds are expected on Wednesday in the wake of Teddy after it crosses eastern Nova Scotia in the morning. These northwesterly winds could potentially gust to 70 to 80 km/h as well before diminishing late in the day. ### A tropical storm watch means that tropical storm conditions (sustained winds near 65 km/h or more) are possible over parts of the region within 36 hours. By nature, a tropical storm also implies the threat of local flooding from heavy rainfall - consult your local area forecast for possible rainfall warnings. Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. Reports of storm conditions and impacts can be emailed directly to NSstorm@canada.ca or by tweeting reports by province using #NSStorm, #NBStorm, #PEStorm, #NLwx, #QCStorm or #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A series of vigorous frontal systems will move across the south coast of BC tonight through Saturday. They will bring periods of heavy rain and strong winds in the first active storm cycle of the the fall season. The first system arrives on Vancouver Island tonight, and will spread to the mainland before Wednesday morning and continue through Thursday. Rainfall intensity will vary through the day and across regions. Over Vancouver Island, total rainfall amounts over the two day period will generally range from 15 to 40 mm, with amounts in excess of 100 mm over West Vancouver Island. For the mainland coast, total rainfall amounts will range from 30 mm to over 50 mm for the two day period. The heaviest rainfall amounts are currently expected for the North Shore. This system will also bring strong southeast winds to the west coast of Vancouver Island tonight. As the system progresses, winds across the Strait of Georgia and surrounding regions will peak early Wednesday morning. The combination of heavy rain with leaves on the ground may lead to localized flooding. Strong winds may also lead to power outages. The wet pattern will continue with more rain expected Friday and Saturday. Rainfall and wind warnings are now in effect for some regions, and will be updated as needed. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-23T20:46:34-00:00

properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Post-tropical Storm Teddy. The next intermediate information statement will be issued by 6:00 a.m. ADT, followed by the next full information statement at 9:00 a.m. Post-Tropical Storm Teddy continues to bring heavy rain, strong winds and heavy pounding surf to much of the Maritimes and southern Newfoundland today. The centre of Teddy is expected to make landfall along the Eastern Shore of Nova Scotia this morning. 1. Summary of basic information at 3:00 a.m. ADT. Location: near 43.4 North 63.5 West. About 137 kilometres south of Halifax. Maximum sustained winds: 120 kilometres per hour. Present movement: north-northeast at 35 kilometres per hour. Minimum central pressure: 957 millibars. Teddy remains a powerful post-tropical storm on its approach towards eastern Nova Scotia this morning with a turn towards the north-northeast. It will continue to weaken as it travels across eastern Nova Scotia and into the southeastern Gulf of St. Lawrence late this morning. The storm will then continue to weaken further as it moves across the eastern Gulf of St. Lawrence this afternoon and towards northern Newfoundland tonight. 2. Public impacts and warnings summary: a. Wind. Wind and Tropical Storm warnings are in effect for the Atlantic coastline of Nova Scotia from Halifax to Cape Breton, where wind gusts of 80 to 110 km/h are occurring or expected this morning. A Tropical Storm warning is in effect for the southwest coast of Newfoundland with wind gusts of 80 to 100 km/h possible into this afternoon. Tropical storm watches remain in effect for northern Nova Scotia, as well as Prince Edward Island and Iles de la Madeleine where winds gusting 70 to 80 possibly reaching 90 km/h are possible this afternoon. Given trees are still in full leaf, these winds could cause limbs to break with some tree falls, likely leading to many power outages. A Wreckhouse wind warning remains in effect for southwestern Newfoundland where winds could gust up to 130 km/h into this evening. b. Rainfall. Rainfall warnings are in effect for all of Nova Scotia except western most regions. Rainfall warnings are also in effect for Prince Edward Island, Les Iles de la Madeleine and parts of the south coast of Newfoundland. Rain, at times heavy, will continue for these areas today as Teddy makes landfall and continues northeast toward Newfoundland. Rainfall amounts generally of 30 to 50 mm have already fallen last night, with the exception of Victoria county in Cape Breton who has already seen 90 to 120 mm fall. With additional rainfall today, total rainfall expected remains at 50 to 75 mm, with upwards of 150 mm possible for Victoria county. c. Surge/Waves. Storm surge warnings are in effect along the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia from Yarmouth County through to eastern Cape Breton County, as well as the southwestern coast of Newfoundland. Large swells will continue to effect the Atlantic coast this morning with waves of up to 8 to 10 metres, and will break higher along parts of the coast. Elevated water levels and large waves are occurring along eastern parts of the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia this morning and will continue to develop over southwestern Newfoundland into this afternoon. There is also a chance for Prince Edward Island and Iles de la Madeleine today. The highest risk is the combination of the very large waves combining with the storm surge to cause dangerous conditions along the Atlantic coasts of Nova Scotia and Newfoundland. Rough and pounding surf, localised flooding and coastal infrastructure damage and erosion are likely in vulnerable areas, even outside of the times of high tide. 3. Marine impacts and warning summary: Hurricane force wind warnings are in effect East Scotian Slope and Sable with storm and gale warnings for remaining waters south of Nova Scotia. Gale warnings are in effect for most Gulf of St. Lawrence waters as well as the southwestern Grand Banks. Teddy will continue to produce waves of 8 to 10 metres this morning. In addition High Water Level warnings continue to be in effect for Eastern Shore and Fourchu. The centre of Teddy passed near Buoy 44150. Both B44150 and B44137 saw significant wave heights of 11 metres with B44137 reaching a peak wave height of 25 metres. Forecaster(s): McArthur ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-09-24T04:59:39-00:00

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High Storm Surge levels and very large waves are expected to impact the coast. Maximum water levels: storm surge of up to 50 cm except higher in areas where large waves break on shore Maximum wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, possibly exceeding 10 metres over eastern areas. Locations: Along the atlantic coast from east of Halifax to eastern Cape Breton. Time span: For the Eastern Shore and Cape Breton, near the high tides near noon. Remarks: Storm surge and very large breaking waves are the main concern and could pose a significant threat. Early today as Teddy approaches, eastern Nova Scotia will see very large wave and significant storm surge. Outside of the times for high tide, there is still a threat for very large waves, rough and pounding surf, and local overwash. The public should exercise extreme caution. ### This is a potentially dangerous situation. High waves combined with the surge may cause damage along the coast. Coastal flooding is possible along the shoreline. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Large waves, pounding surf and elevated sea water levels are expected, possibly exceeding high astronomical tide. Wave heights: generally 6 to 8 metres with higher waves possible, breaking upon approach to shore. Locations: Burin and Connaigre Peninsulas. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Long-period swells and very large waves are expected to build along the south coast as Post-Tropical Storm Teddy tracks towards the island. These waves may coincide with high tide to produce elevated water levels, with potential for local flooding and coastal erosion, especially along south-facing shorelines. Damage to coastal infrastructure may occur. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: High Water Level Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels are expected or occurring. Maximum water levels: storm surge near 50 cm except higher in areas where large waves break on shore. Maximum wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, possibly exceeding 10 metres over eastern areas. Locations: from Shelburne County east to Sydney. Time span: For Southwestern Shore: near high tide near midnight. For Eastern Shore and eastern Cape Breton: near high tides near midnight and near noon Wednesday. Remarks: The main risk is for very large waves, rough and pounding surf, and a threat for rip currents. 3-5 metre waves at the coast will build to 7-9 metres later this evening. The high waves will persist into the overnight period and into Wednesday over eastern areas. Outside of the times for high tide, there is still a threat for very large waves, rough and pounding surf, and local overwash. The public should observe extreme caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

properties.Title: Tropical Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Tropical storm force winds of 70 gusting to 100 km/h over exposed areas from Post-tropical Storm Teddy can be expected over the above regions. Tropical storm force winds ahead of now Post-Tropical Storm Teddy will continue to affect Nova Scotia tonight, accompanied by rain at times heavy. A second swath of strong southerly winds will briefly affect eastern mainland Nova Scotia and Cape Breton early Wednesday morning. Potential wind gusts: 80 to 90 km/h possibly reaching 110 km/h over exposed areas and along parts of the coast. Locations: Coastal regions of mainland Nova Scotia and Cape Breton. Time span: this evening. A second period of strong winds can be expected over eastern Nova Scotia Wednesday morning. Remarks: Tropical storm force easterly winds are occuring over much of Nova Scotia ahead of Post-Tropical Storm Teddy. Winds are expected to gust to 80 to 100 km/h over exposed areas and along parts of the coast this evening. A period of very strong southerly winds gusting to 90 to 110 km/h will affect eastern mainland Nova Scotia and Cape Breton Wednesday morning as the center of Teddy crosses eastern Nova Scotia. ### These winds could break tree branches potentially resulting in downed utility lines. A tropical storm warning means that tropical storm conditions (sustained winds near 65 km/h or more) are expected over parts of the region within 24 hours. By nature, a tropical storm also implies the threat of local flooding from heavy rainfall - consult your local area forecast for possible rainfall warnings. Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. Reports of storm conditions and impacts can be emailed directly to NSstorm@canada.ca or by tweeting reports by province using #NSStorm, #NBStorm, #PEStorm, #NLwx, #QCStorm or #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels with large waves are expected near the coast. Locations: south facing shorelines from Port aux Basques to Burgeo-Ramea. Maximum wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Time span: continuing until this evening, with the most severe conditions expected this afternoon. Next high tide: 1 P.M. to 6 P.M. today. Remarks: Large waves and pounding surf will produce higher than normal water levels along the coast, especially near high tide. These large waves can cause damage to coastal infrastructure, especially at locations that have been prone to impacts during similar events in the past. ### Coastal flooding is possible along the shoreline. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-09-23T23:51:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-23T07:52:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0354979351.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southerly 90 to 110 km/h for eastern areas today. Locations: Eastern Shore to Victoria County Time span: this morning until about noon. Remarks: Winds will strengthen today for eastern parts of the province as Teddy approaches from the south and crosses the province today. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-23T16:59:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-23T07:43:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3554525682.2020
Area: Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Guysborough County, Richmond County, Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: High Water Level Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels are expected or occurring. Locations: south facing shorelines from Port aux Basques to Burgeo-Ramea. Maximum wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Time span: continuing until this evening, with the most severe conditions expected this afternoon. First high tide: continuing until 4 A.M. this morning. Second high tide: 1 P.M. to 6 P.M. today. Remarks: Large waves and pounding surf can cause damage to coastal infrastructure, especially at locations that have been prone to impacts during similar events in the past. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 130 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: this afternoon and early this evening. Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds are expected to redevelop this afternoon as Post-Tropical Storm Teddy approaches southwestern Newfoundland. Winds will ease early this evening as they shift to southwesterly. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-09-23T23:50:23-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Locations: Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick. Time span: Into this afternoon. Remarks: Periods of rain will persist into this afternoon. Additional rainfall amounts of 10 to 20 mm are expected. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-23T15:59:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-23T07:41:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1347949771.2020
Area: Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Heavy rainfall is forecast for Howe Sound as a vigorous, moist frontal system arrives on the coast overnight. Even after the front passes Wednesday morning, moist air will continue funneling up the fjord. Rainfall amounts of 40-65 mm are forecast by Thursday morning. Moderate to strong southerly winds of 40-60 km/h will accompany the frontal system on Wednesday and gradually diminish Wednesday evening. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-23T15:11:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-22T23:12:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1023318119.2020
Area: Howe Sound
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A low pressure system approaching Baffin Island will bring very strong southeasterly winds along with rain at times mixed with wet snow to Kimmirut region tonight and Wednesday. The strongest winds are expected overnight and Wednesday morning with wind gusts near 90 km/h forecast. Winds will moderate thereafter however this system will stall near Baffin Island and get reinforced by the remnants of Hurricane Teddy bringing ongoing precipitation to the region until at least Friday. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-23T19:59:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-23T04:02:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2166845908.2020
Area: Kimmirut
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. An intense frontal system is moving rapidly toward the North Coast of BC. By this evening southeasterly winds 90 gusting to 110 km/h are expected to develop over Haida Gwaii. As the front passes through, winds will fall below warning after midnight, but remain quite strong. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-23T10:59:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-22T22:53:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2026620168.2020
Area: Haida Gwaii
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Large waves, rough and pounding surf, and elevated water levels are expected, possibly approaching warning level. Wave heights: 3 to 5 metres with possibly high waves, breaking upon approach to shore. Location: Iles-de-la-Madeleine. Time span: near high tide today. Remarks: Long period swell and large wind waves associated with Hurricane Teddy are expected to impact east facing coastlines of Les Iles-de-la-Madeleine today. There is a risk of local flooding and coastal erosion, especially during high tide. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-23T20:14:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-23T07:51:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2227157781.2020
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada
